How much food is available in a given ar: A trait with a function.
Nonaggressive social interactions and associations between individuals.
Conflict; aggressive interactions between individuals.
Vocalizations emitted by social animals in response to danger.
A similar trait found in different species that arose independently.
Relating to the anus and genitals.
The time of year when females are receptive to mating.
The primate family that includes marmosets and tamarins.
Organisms whose diet consists primarily of animal tissue.
A temporary alliance between individuals.
The branch of ecology that deals with the relationships and interactions between different organisms that occupy the same habitat.
An examination of the similarities and differences between two things, such as two primate species.
Members of the same species.
When individuals other than the mother and father help raise the offspring.
The ability to avoid detection by other organisms, such as predators.
A distinctive pattern of behavior shared by multiple individuals in a social group, which persists over time and is acquired through social learning.
The transmission of behavior from one generation to the next through observation and imitation.
Understanding and highlighting the theory and research of non-Western individuals and perspectives.
A species that comes after the ancestor species.
Competition that involves physical interaction between individuals, such as fighting.
To leave one’s group or area. This may or may not involve joining another group.
How food is spread out.
Active during the day.
The ranked organization of individuals established by the outcome of aggressive-submissive interactions.
Being of high rank.
The relationship between organisms and their physical surroundings.
A form of tourism that focuses on nature-based attractions to provide learning opportunities and that uses economically and ecologically sustainable practices.
The study of animal behavior.

Societies in which group composition is flexible, such as chimpanzee and spider monkey societies. Individuals may break up into smaller feeding groups (fission) and combine into larger groups (fusion).
An individual’s ability to survive and reproduce relative to other members of the same species.
Organisms whose diet consists primarily of leaves.
The act of searching for food.
Organisms whose diet consists primarily of fruit.
Picking through the fur of another individual for cleaning or bonding purposes.
Members of different species.
The idea that the parts of a system interconnect and interact to make up the whole.
The area that a group or individual uses over a given period of time (often over a year).
A similar trait found in different species because it was inherited from a common ancestor.
Movement of an individual into a new group or community.
Competition that does not involve physical interaction between individuals, such as eating food before another individual arrives at the food site.
The killing of infants of one’s own species.
Natural; as in behavior that comes naturally.
Organisms whose diets consist primarily of insects.
The typical length of time between one birth and the next for a species.
The selection for traits that enhance the ability of the members of one sex to attract the attention of the other.
Selection for traits that enhance the ability of members of one sex to compete amongst themselves.
A way of describing which male(s) and female(s) mate.
The chemical changes that take place in an organism that turn nutrients into energy.
Cooperatively attacking or harassing a predator.
A mating system in which one male mates with one female.
A group that consists of multiple adult males, multiple adult females, and their dependent offspring.
A group that consists of two or more adult males, one breeding female, their dependent offspring, and non-breeding females.
When different species work together, with each benefiting from the interaction.
The role of a species in its environment; how it meets its needs for food, shelter, etc.
Active at night.
Conveying information through scent.
Organisms whose diet consists of plant and animal matter.
A strong, long-term relationship between two individuals.
An organism that lives in or on another organism.
Any time or energy a parent devotes to the current offspring that enhances its survival (and eventual reproductive success) at the expense of the parent’s ability to invest in the next offspring.
Remaining in the group of one’s birth.
Raising one’s hair or fur in an effort to look bigger.
A mating system in which multiple males mate with a single breeding female.
A mating system in which multiple males mate with multiple females.
A mating system in which one male mates with multiple females.
An association between two or more different species that involves behavioral changes in at least one of them to maintain the association.
All primate species that occur in an area.
A scientist who studies primate behavior and/or ecology.
The scientific field that studies primate behavior and/or ecology.
Refers to the way in which animals move about their environment.
A term used to describe females who are ready for sexual reproduction (i.e., not pregnant or nursing).
An individual’s genetic contribution to future generations, often measured through the number of offspring produced.
The prevention or inhibition of reproduction of healthy adults.
Term that describes the male who lives with a group of females.
The process by which seeds move away from the plant that produced them in preparation for germination and becoming a new plant.
The systematic use of signals to refer to objects in the environment.
When males and females of a species have different morphological traits.
The selection for traits that increase mating success. This occurs via intersexual selection and intrasexual selection.

Area of the hindquarters that change in size, shape, and often color over the course of a female’s reproductive cycle, reaching maximum size at ovulation. Occurs in many primate species that live in Africa and Asia.
When males and females of a species have similar morphological traits.
A group that consists of one adult male, multiple adult female, and their dependent offspring.
A group that consists of one adult male, one adult female, and their dependent offspring.
The idea that new behaviors can be acquired by observing and imitating others.
A way of describing the typical number of males and females of all age classes that live together.
Transfer of something from one individual to another; this can include parasites, information, or cultural traditions.
The tendency to form social groups.
Living alone.
The ability to differentiate conspecifics from members of other species.
Being of low rank.
Conveying information through touch.
A home range whose boundary is defended from intrusion by conspecifics.
The group of animals characterized by an internal spinal column or backbone. This includes fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals.
Watchful behavior used to detect potential danger, usually in the form of predators or potential competitors.
Conveying information through signals that can be seen.
Conveying information through signals that can be heard.
